A C++ implmentation of camera class

May 31, 2017

Camera is the starting point of perceiving the world, and it’s probably the single most component in the computer vision library.

The camera class should have the following methods:

  • IO: read to/write from file:
    • intrinsic and extrinsic parameters: type 0;
    • projection matrix.
  • set intrinsic and extrinsic parameters;
  • camera coordinate system: camera center and axes;
  • set/get matrix , , , , and ;
  • project/unproject;
  • compute depth
  • possiblly more

Intrinsic and extrinsic parameter

  • is a orthonormal matrix, where each column is the axes of the world coordinates in the camera’s coordinate system. It’s apprent in the following example: ;
  • is the camera center in the world coordinate system, while is the world origin in the camera coordinate system since .

Recovering

Decompose is the easiest, since is invertible, and is the fourth column of the camera matrix , thus

Recovering and

We know that all full rank matrices can be decomposed into an upper-triangular matrix and an orthogonal matrix by using RQ-decomposition, and this is exactly the case with and . RQ decomposition is normally unavailable in many numeric libraries. A nice post in Solem’s vision blog gives an implementation of this decomposition.

The problem is RQ-decomposition is not unique, since the sign of the diagonal elements can be flipped. Let’s first assume that the diagonal elements of are positive, which is not necessarily true. Nonetheless, we can achieve a unique solution by enforcing non-negative diagonal elements. An elegant solution is

% non-negative diagonal elements
T = sign(K);
K = K * T;
R = T * R % the inverse of T is itself
